title: Struggle with Eating Disorder
content: The individual opens up in detail about her struggle with an eating disorder. She has only recently overcome a 15 year eating disorder. She struggled with anorexia for a short time and went on to binge eating and bulimia. Even before she thought about going off to college, she was in the depths of that disorder. She was also struggling a lot with depression. At age 16 she had already attempted suicide twice. She was hospitalized for a good part of grade 11. This escalated into adulthood and only very recently has she started to work on her mental health. A lot of her advances have come as she has developed a sense of purpose in life and ultimately finding happiness.

title: Depression and Eating Disorder
content: The depression and eating disorder came on simultaneously for multiple reasons. She grew up with the idea that unless she was the best at something, or did everything and excelled at everything, she didn’t really have value as a human. This is one aspect of where the depression and eating disorder came from. She also experienced some sexual trauma around that age. There were 2 instances, and it happened with people she really respected and trusted. That coupled with a toxic home environment.

title: Struggle with Bulimia
content: The individual struggled with bulimia. She would act out these behaviors of binge eating and then purging. It was just constant. There was a point where it was probably every day of the week for 5 years. It slowed down when she got to university. She didn’t know anything about appetite regulating hormones or the energy requirements for the sports she was doing.

title: Complications associated with Bulimia
content: With the constant flow of acidity up and down the esophagus, she didn't have any issues with her teeth. She doesn’t know about electrolyte abnormalities because she never had routine blood work back then. Thankfully she never had any esophageal erosion for the acid.

title: Prevalence of Eating Disorders
content: The prevalence of eating disorders is a lot greater in females than males. But in the last 10 years it’s increasing in young boys. The individual recalls something on the order of 60% of high school girls in the US have reported to struggle with low confidence and a negative sense of self and body image. The prevalence of eating disorders is lower but but it’s still scarily high.

title: Training and Nutrition Program
content: The individual builds out what a training and nutrition program might look like for a female who wants to gain 5 lbs of muscle and lose 5 lbs of fat. Even if you’re not aspiring to be a bodybuilder, everybody is somewhat interested in improving their physique, and therefore there is a lot of value in this episode about building muscle (particularly for females) which is important for longevity.

title: Desire for Control and Obsession with Body Image
content: It wasn’t body image she was concerned about, it was control. Anytime she felt stressed, anxious, etc, the desire to control came back. She crafted an environment that shielded her from stresses, potential triggers so she could live in control, and that gave her comfort. As she became more involved in sports, her physique did change. She started to connect the dots with her athletic performance, superior physique, low body fat, more muscle. Then the praise she would get externally from people became the obsession. She became obsessed with how she looked, and that was where she found her self-worth. That was where she felt valued and appreciated, and respected. And for a good part of her life, it became her identity, and that just fueled the disorder.

title: Therapy and Coping Mechanisms
content: Through a lot of hard work and regular therapy, she managed to break the cycle. Once every 6 weeks is not enough. When she got into therapy at age 16, she saw a therapist once every 6 weeks. She saw a specialist who worked with women’s health issues, eating disorders and nutrition. In her post-college life, she had periods where she felt like she was managing the symptoms and feelings. But as soon as things became stressful, or if she had extra assignments due, or if she needed to work 2 full weekends back to back for financial reasons, she just lost it and coped with extreme binging, purging.

title: Road to Recovery
content: She ended up admitting herself to rehab. This incorporated counseling, yoga practices, different types of relaxation techniques. One of the owners worked through nutrition. It was an intense 7-day stay. It opened her eyes to the benefits of relaxation, meditation, and the value of communication and being transparent and open. Once she moved to America she got herself into weekly therapy… it got her on the right path. She’s had a therapy session every week since 2016.

title: Breakthroughs and Self-Development
content: The breakthroughs that occurred with that type of more consistent therapy made her accountable. It made her speak, talk, and reflect back on her past. She gained appreciation and understanding of why she felt the way she did. This was incredibly valuable. She started discussing, “What are some of the dysfunctions in these beliefs?” She started deconstructing different sets of thoughts. And talked about how they might look differently for a healthy mind. This was a time of a lot of self development, reading, and finding herself spiritually.

title: Overcoming Eating Disorders
content: Once she didn’t have these outlets, it forced her to get real with her intention for eating. It forced her to be mindful, to slow down, to become present with her meals and really listen to what her body was saying. This is really hard, because if you’ve restrained from certain foods, alcohol, or drugs for a long period of time, all you do is think about that thing. After this she started having a little more compassion for herself and forgiveness. Reducing the amount of judgment she had for herself. Once she started being kinder to herself, she started to make more progress.

title: Weight Gain and Self-Compassion
content: This was 1 of the first strategies she had to work through for her anxiety. At this point she had also developed a social anxiety. Now part of that process was discussing the feelings and starting to identify the new feeling she had, now that she’d gained weight. This led to horrible thoughts about herself. Around this time her therapist asked her, “What would you say to a client?” This led her to start treating herself like she would her clients.

title: Shift in Thinking and Self-Perception
content: A shift in thinking occurred. What does friendship have to do with your physical appearance? Nothing. She realized she didn’t have any logical reasoning for believing this was true. Those relationships aren’t built on your aesthetic, they’re built on your character. So when she started talking to herself that way, she realized she can still have fun and it has nothing to do with the weight on the scale or her body fat percentage.

title: Bodybuilding and Health
content: Bodybuilding is often seen as the pinnacle of exercise and nutrition as it pertains to aesthetics. It requires rigorous training and strict nutrition. Competing in the drug-free category means relying solely on training and nutrition, without any additional biochemistry. Bodybuilders often aim to achieve a low body fat percentage, sometimes as low as 10-11%. However, this can lead to health issues such as the cessation of the menstrual cycle. Even with the return of calories back to a normal amount and the return of body fat back to normal, healthy levels, the menstrual cycle may not return immediately. This is attributed to the years of extreme dieting and exercise.

title: Health Risks of Bodybuilding
content: Many question if bodybuilding is a healthy sport, given the extreme leanness required. From an evolutionary standpoint, extreme leanness can interfere with fertility. It's not ideal for females to be that lean. Not all women lose their menstrual cycle when they compete, but it does become irregular. It can take years to recover a regular menstrual cycle through a process of reverse dieting. A recovery diet allows for the gain of some body fat and an off season where a good amount of calories are consumed to fuel the body to the point where hormones function as they should. However, 50% of women do completely lose their cycle.

title: Training and Nutrition for Bodybuilding
content: The training and nutrition for bodybuilding involves a bulk building phase, a cutting phase, and a recovery diet phase. The process is the same for professional athletes and those who simply want to improve their physique. The approach comes down to the individual's definition of what's bulky to them. It takes years of consistent nutrition and training to achieve a high level of muscularity. Training intensity is one of the principles that needs to be increased over a training lifespan to facilitate hypertrophy.

title: Training Principles for Muscle Hypertrophy
content: Rate of Perceived Exertion (RPE) is a measure of training intensity. Another measure used is Repetitions in Reserve (RIR), which indicates how many repetitions are left in reserve up to hitting failure. Training intensity needs to be increased over a training lifespan to facilitate hypertrophy. During a building phase, near failure sets are performed. The training is split among 5 days, focusing on specific muscle groups that one wants to build. For example, glute hypertrophy and shoulder hypertrophy are often focused on. The training program varies, with rest days and deloads incorporated to give the body the recovery it needs.

title: Leg Exercises
content: The squat, the deadlift to some extent, and the step-up are exercises that hit the quads. Leg extensions are a simple exercise with minimal set-up. Different leg press variations and different squat variations that get our knee into a position where there’s far more forward knee travel are beneficial. If someone’s had a history of knee injuries, that’s something that you would want to take very slowly and very progressively. Single leg work helps with imbalances. It’s very easy with lots of repeat training, lots of repeating the same movements where we have a bit of a discrepancy. Incorporate at least 1 single leg exercise for every session.

title: Hamstring Exercises
content: Seated hamstring curl is better able to isolate your hamstrings than a prone hamstring curl. When you’re in a seated hamstring machine, you’ve already got tension on the hamstrings because we’re sitting in this upright position. It’s a lot more tension on the hamstrings than if you’re in a prone position where your hips are far more open. Romanian deadlift (RDL) is a hinging exercise and you’re shifting your hips back to lengthen the hamstrings. You are loading the hamstrings in that exercise. You can do it with dumbbells, barbells, or kettlebells.

title: Calf Exercises
content: Research shows seated calf presses tends to be a little bit better for hypertrophy outcomes. Neutral stance and toes facing out tend to do better for optimizing hypertrophy of different aspects of your calf.

title: Upper Body Exercises
content: One of the main things again that does differ between men and women’s training programs is chest volume. Women, even in the fitness category seem to be judged on glutes, hamstrings, shoulders, quads. Some people need a lot of chest training or conversely back training to correct their posture. If they’re hunched forward, kyphotic and have that rounding, they probably have extremely tight pectorals and weak back musculature. Here she would do a lot more volume on the back and probably wouldn’t spend any time on chest work.

title: Shoulder Training
content: Lots of training for the shoulders is beneficial. One of her favorites is the scrape the rack shoulder press. You are up against a squat rack with a barbell on. You can do it kneeling or standing (she likes kneeling because it eliminates the ability to cheat, when you’re standing you can use a bit of momentum to keep pushing).

title: Shoulder Exercises and Mobility
content: You have to have a good range of motion and mobility for your shoulders. Another favorite is the behind the neck shoulder press, on a Smith machine. This is done because it keeps the person in a very safe, fixed plane. Lateral raises are another thing people can do to improve their medial shoulder and rear delts. You can do a reverse pec fly where you’re kind of pushing away. If you have access to cables, you can do a cable crossover to hit your rear delts. Face pulls are another exercise.

title: Importance of Nutrition and Protein during Muscle Building
content: The other key piece to the success of muscle building is diet. To optimize hypertrophy you need to take in anywhere from 1.8 g protein/ kg lean body mass to 3 g/kg. This also depends on the individuals dietary preferences and what food they like. Consistency is important in protein intake. It impacts your energy balance because protein has a far higher thermogenic effect than carbohydrates or fat.

title: Calorie Surplus for Muscle Gain
content: To gain lean mass, a small calorie surplus, 10-20% surplus, is recommended. This decision is based on the individual’s comfort with adding body fat. Most muscle mass is gained around that 20% mark. Excess body fat gain is seen going up to 40% or 60% above maintenance calories.

title: Nutrition and Training during Fat Loss Phase
content: The goal of dieting is to keep as high calories as possible with as little increase in activity as possible, while still achieving a targeted rate of weekly weight loss. Beyond a loss of 1.5% body weight/ week, people start losing a greater % of muscle mass and lean tissue (as opposed to fat).

title: Reverse Diet after Cutting Phase
content: After a competition or a period of dieting, a reverse diet is recommended. This involves slowly reintroducing calories post-diet. This process still feels like a diet but helps prevent rapid weight gain. The goal is to find your new maintenance calories.

title: Weight Loss and Maintenance
content: You can assess that by looking a how much weight you lost over the final weeks of the fat-loss phase. For this woman, if her maintenance was 2000 coming in, it’s probably going to be a lot lower. It depends on her fat-loss phase and how extreme, how much deficit she needed to lose weight. Did she do a lot of cardio to create the deficit? What was the intensity of the cardio like? She could have lost some muscle during the fat-loss phase. You will always lose muscle mass when you attempt a fat-loss phase, but the leaner you get, the greater the risk of that muscle loss is, because you no longer have that caloric cushioning to support that. Her metabolism when we go back to her new maintenance calories, after she’s added more muscle, will require fewer calories than at the start of that reverse diet. There may be some work that needs to be done reversing to get her back to that 2000 calories she was on. She may not be able to go straight back to that. It takes weeks. The way to do it is with slow, incremental increases week-by-week. Observe the weight gain and adjust accordingly.

title: Female-specific Training Considerations
content: Differences between men and women. Men and women may have a preference for targeting different muscles groups. People may have actually heard somewhere along their fitness journey that women tend to do better with higher rep ranges, and males do better with lower rep ranges. Part of that is due to differences in sex hormones, and that has an impact on muscle fiber type. Females have a greater % of Type I muscle fibers than males. The positive consequence of that difference there for females is that it means that we are better able to transport nutrients into the tissues and also clear different metabolites during activities. The benefit is that women tend fatigable less when it comes to training. Women also tend to do better utilizing fatty acids. In both the fed and fasted state. This means women are less reliant on glycolytic pathways or anaerobic processes. This means women do better when it come to recovery.

title: Effects of Menstrual Cycle on Training
content: There has been more information recently on effects of the menstrual cycle on hypertrophy outcomes and strength training. 4 studies come to mind and half of them show that during the second phase (the luteal phase) of the menstrual cycle, that strength decreases for females during training. This is when progesterone is high and estrogen is low. When progesterone is low, about 50% of women report feeling a lot better with their training. Their performance is better and strength is improved. When it comes to programming for females, as a default Holly will set deloads on or around their menstrual cycle.

title: Training Post-Pregnancy and Menopause
content: The transition from higher levels of sex hormones (testerone and estrogen) to low levels during menopause is really hard on females. There is so much benefit to getting your hormone levels tested. Getting somebody back into the normal reference ranges with hormone replacement therapy has huge benefits for their quality of life. People are much more motivated to be active. Women who aren’t proactive and on some kind of hormone replacement therapy tend to come in with extremely low calorie intake and extreme exercise output. They’re feeling frustrated because the eat nothing, train multiple times a day, and can’t lose fat. It’s difficult when you’ve been dealing with those negative symptoms for a long period of time. Naturally, if you don’t feel good, you’re not going to train.

title: Bodybuilding and Mental Health
content: She feels very conflicted about coming back and staying because she doesn’t have the same feeling towards competing anymore. She no longer desires the leanness. She can do the process. But now she’s no longer attached to the body. She wants to be an advocate to help people realize what they can do if they do the work. Currently she is so passionate about mental health. She may potentially step back from everything that she does in the fitness industry and go back to school to do a PhD in the area of neuropsychology or mental health and eating disorders. She wants to help people.

title: Longevity, Bone Mineral Density, and Wellness
content: Her approach now is all about longevity. Her ideals about what life should be to be truly happy doesn’t involve slaving away in the gym anymore. It doesn’t look like being a lifelong competitor. This doesn’t mean she will let herself go and not have any interest in exercise. She wants to remain functionally fit. She thinks her training will gravitate away from the gym some and incorporate more hobbies that keep her active and functioning well. But she will always lift because she knows the benefits of resistance training. She’s very content with the idea that she can still be healthy at a much higher body fat %. As long as she has muscle mass underneath that body fat. Muscle mass is protective in so many ways. Reducing risk of bone degenerative conditions like osteoporosis. Resistance training, anything that applies tension and stress on the bone, to get those little bone-creating cells to ramp up. Training has given her greater bone density.

title: Importance of Muscle Mass and Bone Density
content: The focus should be on how much muscle mass patients can put on and how much they can increase the density of their bones rather than their weight. If your weight is predominately lean tissue, and you’re maintaining the integrity of your skeletal structure, you’re going to live a better life.

title: Shifting Focus from Aesthetics
content: There needs to be a shift from the belief that one needs to look a certain way. The fixation on the scale, body fat, and cellulite should be less of a concern. The focus should be on the important things of life.

title: Long-term Health Importance
content: Long-term health is important. Staying active has benefits for mental health.

title: Avoiding Social Media's Thin Ideals
content: There needs to be a big shift in what is delivered to patients and clients. Social media's thin ideals and filters can be misleading. Unfollowing accounts that are only focused on the aesthetic can be beneficial.

title: Personal Development and Happiness
content: Spending time on personal development and learning about how to change your mind, how to be happy, what is life’s purpose, and how to break habits can lead to happiness. This means there’s less need for the aesthetic stuff.
